node.title: Ukraine pushes U.N. to stop buying Russian goods and services
node.description: The U.N. paid Russia $2.5 billion for things like transport services and equipment in the 8 years leading up to Putin's latest invasion. Those contracts continue.

node.title: Subway attack witnesses recall "smoke and blood and people screaming"
node.description: At least 10 people were shot at the subway station in Brooklyn, New York, with five people in critical but stable condition, officials said Tuesday morning.

node.title: Putin's war on Ukraine drives thousands of Russians to flee their country
node.description: An estimated 200,000 people left Russia during the first 10 days of the war, and some now lament their friends back home accepting Putin's narrative.

node.title: TransUnion "unwilling or incapable" of operating lawfully, feds say
node.description: Consumer watchdog says credit reporting giant continued misleading consumers even after getting fined.

node.title: Russian hackers targeted Ukrainian power company, say Ukrainian officials
node.description: Ukrainian officials said Russian hackers tried last Friday to attack power substations of a private energy company and cut power to two million people.

node.title: BA.2 now behind nearly all new COVID cases in the Northeast
node.description: As prevalence of the Omicron subvariant nears 90% nationwide, officials around the world are already tracking the rise of dozens of new potential variants.

node.title: New York lieutenant governor indicted in campaign finance scheme
node.description: He faces five counts, including bribery, wire fraud and falsification of records.

node.title: Worried about an IRS audit? Here's how to avoid getting flagged
node.description: Experts say there are a number of things people can do to lower the chance of getting audited by the IRS.

node.title: Oklahoma governor signs bill to make almost all abortions illegal
node.description: Under the bill, anyone convicted of performing an abortion would face up to 10 years in prison and a $100,000 fine.

node.title: 17-year-old Olympic sailor dies while training with twin sister
node.description: Eya Guezguez was training with her twin sister Sarra alongside their national team when their boat capsized due to strong winds.

node.title: An unexpected ride for a hungry javelina
node.description: The piglike animal was released without injury after its late-night snack.

node.title: U.K. leader Boris Johnson fined for breaking his own COVID rules
node.description: The treasury chief, Britain's 2nd highest government official, was also among those fined for attending parties during the height of England's coronavirus lockdown.

node.title: Multiple people reported shot at New York subway station
node.description: Multiple people were shot at a subway station in the Sunset Park neighborhood of Brooklyn, officials told CBS News.

node.title: Shanghai lockdown lifted for some, but millions still trapped and angry
node.description: China's biggest city entered its 3rd week of a draconian coronavirus lockdown with anger mounting among its 25 million residents, with no end in sight for most of them.

node.title: U.K. says all options on table if Russia used chemical weapons in Ukraine
node.description: Unverified social media reports allege that Russian forces may have used chemical weapons in the besieged city of Mariupol.

node.title: Inflation accelerated to 8.5% in March, highest since 1981
node.description: Price of gasoline, food and shelter rose in March, driving inflation to its highest level in more than 40 years.

node.title: Russian court rejects appeal by jailed former U.S. Marine
node.description: Trevor Reed's family said they had "little hope" for his appeal, but U.S. Ambassador John Sullivan called the court's decision "very disappointing."

node.title: Transgender Disney heir rips Florida's "Don't Say Gay" bill
node.description: The 30-year-old biology teacher said states are trying to make often-difficult journeys for transgender people even harder.

node.title: Soon there will be just 3 Kmart stores in the U.S.
node.description: The former retail giant is closing its fourth remaining store, in Avenel, New Jersey, on April 16.

node.title: South Dakota House to vote on impeaching attorney general
node.description: Ravnsborg struck and killed a pedestrian on the shoulder of a highway in September 2020.

node.title: California weighs shift to 32-hour workweek
node.description: Bill would make it the first state in the nation to adopt a four-day week for some employees.

node.title: Latest report on state of Black America paints grim picture
node.description: Many troubling historic trends are continuing almost unabated, according to the National Urban League's annual assessment.

node.title: Olympian's mother killed by stray bullet while sewing in her home
node.description: Police said investigators believe the shooting was drug-related and had nothing to do with Mabel Martinez.

node.title: EPA to try to fight high gas prices with ethanol blend
node.description: It's the Biden administration's latest attempt to bring gas prices down for Americans.

node.title: More than 40 killed as storm unleashes landslides on Philippine villages
node.description: The search for survivors in one hard-hit village was suspended as night fell and ongoing rain from tropical storm Megi complicated rescue efforts.

node.title: One killed after teens in body armor take turns shooting each other
node.description: The teens had been taking turns shooting at each other while wearing a vest which contained a form of body armor, police said.

node.title: Family seeks Ukrainian nephew's release from San Diego immigrant detention center
node.description: Ivan Yerashov is a typical 14-year-old, who's into sports and his computer. Now, he's also a Ukrainian refugee.

node.title: Climber dies day after celebrating making it to top of Himalayan peak
node.description: Antonios  Sykaris was an experienced climber who had summited five other mountains higher than 8,000 meters, according to his website.

node.title: With his conviction tossed, man freed after serving 18 years for murder
node.description: Keith Carnes insisted all along he didn't kill a rival drug dealer in 2003.

node.title: As battle looms in Ukraine's east, US commits to providing weapons to Ukraine
node.description: Russian forces pounded targets in eastern Ukraine with missiles and artillery as Austria's leader planned to meet with Russian President Vladimir Putin.
